articles.headline: Auction Off for a Leader in Apparel
articles.snippet: The Jones Apparel Group plans to abandon its months-long auction after failing to find a buyer willing to meet its price.
articles.abstract: The Jones Apparel Group plans to abandon its months-long auction after failing to find a buyer willing to meet its price.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Jones Apparel Group, the $5 billion clothing conglomerate that owns Barneys New York, plans to abandon its months-long auction after failing to find a buyer willing to meet its price, people involved in the process said last night.
articles.byline: By Andrew Ross Sorkin and Michael Barbaro

articles.headline: A Woman to Be Chief at PepsiCo
articles.snippet: Indra K. Nooyi’s promotion will make PepsiCo the largest United States company by market capitalization led by a woman.
articles.abstract: Indra K. Nooyi’s promotion will make PepsiCo the largest United States company by market capitalization led by a woman.
articles.lead_paragraph: PepsiCo said yesterday that its president and chief financial officer, Indra K. Nooyi, would succeed Steven S. Reinemund as chief executive on Oct. 1, a move that makes the company one of the largest led by a woman.

articles.headline: Dell Will Recall Batteries in PC’s
articles.snippet: Dell is recalling 4.1 million notebook computer batteries because they could erupt in flames. It will be the largest safety recall in the industry’s history.
articles.abstract: Dell is recalling 4.1 million notebook computer batteries because they could erupt in flames. It will be the largest safety recall in the industry’s history.
articles.lead_paragraph: Dell is recalling 4.1 million notebook computer batteries because they could erupt in flames, the company said yesterday. It will be the largest safety recall in the history of the consumer electronics industry, the Consumer Product Safety Commission said.

articles.headline: Fragile Cease-Fire Allows Thousands to Return Home
articles.snippet: The Israeli Army said early Tuesday that Hezbollah had fired several rockets late Monday but that all had landed in southern Lebanon.
articles.abstract: The Israeli Army said early Tuesday that Hezbollah had fired several rockets late Monday but that all had landed in southern Lebanon.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Tuesday, Aug. 15 — Tens, perhaps hundreds, of thousands of Lebanese clogged roads to the south on Monday night as a tense, fragile cease-fire began between Israeli troops and Hezbollah guerrillas.

articles.headline: Maybe the Toughest Job Aloft
articles.snippet: Flight attendants, whose profession was once considered glamorous, have seen workloads and stress levels rise, but not their pay.
articles.abstract: Flight attendants, whose profession was once considered glamorous, have seen workloads and stress levels rise, but not their pay.
articles.lead_paragraph: Jer’i Conway was the envy of her friends in 1969 when she became a flight attendant at United Airlines. She planned to stay about 18 months and then thought she would leave to be married, but the perks of free travel and other benefits kept her silver wings firmly on her uniform through the industry’s best and leanest years.

articles.headline: A Generic Drug Tale, With an Ending Yet to Be Written
articles.snippet: The Justice Department is investigating a deal involving Bristol-Myers Squibb, Sanofi-Aventis and their big-selling drug Plavix.
articles.abstract: The Justice Department is investigating a deal involving Bristol-Myers Squibb, Sanofi-Aventis and their big-selling drug Plavix.
articles.lead_paragraph: The opening chapters of a draft autobiography sit amid the hundreds of pill bottles and mound of legal documents in Bernard C. Sherman’s office. It will be the story of a brainy kid born in Toronto who becomes Canada’s richest generic drug mogul.

articles.headline: Testing How Long the Mideast Cease-Fire Can Last
articles.snippet: The fate of the cease-fire may lie in whether the Lebanese regard the conflict as a victory or blame Hezbollah for the destruction.
articles.abstract: The fate of the cease-fire may lie in whether the Lebanese regard the conflict as a victory or blame Hezbollah for the destruction.

articles.headline: Census Shows Growth of Immigrants
articles.snippet: The number of immigrants living in U.S. households rose 16 percent over the last five years, fueled largely by recent arrivals from Mexico.
articles.abstract: The number of immigrants living in U.S. households rose 16 percent over the last five years, fueled largely by recent arrivals from Mexico.
articles.lead_paragraph: The number of immigrants living in American households rose 16 percent over the last five years, fueled largely by recent arrivals from Mexico, according to fresh data released by the Census Bureau.

articles.headline: Marketers Trace Paths Users Leave on Internet
articles.snippet: Internet companies are analyzing records of what their users search for to target advertising directly to them.
articles.abstract: Internet companies are analyzing records of what their users search for to target advertising directly to them.

articles.headline: Fragile Cease-Fire Allows Thousands to Return Home
articles.snippet: Tens, perhaps hundreds, of thousands of Lebanese clogged roads to the south on Monday night as a tense, fragile cease-fire began between Israeli troops and Hezbollah guerrillas.     While the cease-fire largely seemed to be holding, the Israeli Ar...
articles.abstract: Tens, perhaps hundreds, of thousands of Lebanese clogged roads to the south on Monday night as a tense, fragile cease-fire began between Israeli troops and Hezbollah guerrillas.     While the cease-fire largely seemed to be holding, the Israeli Army said early Tuesday that Hezbollah had fired several rockets, possibly Katyushas, late Monday but that all had landed in southern Lebanon. The military said that it seemed to be a possible effort at provocation but that it had not responded.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Tuesday, Aug. 15 - Tens, perhaps hundreds, of thousands of Lebanese clogged roads to the south on Monday night as a tense, fragile cease-fire began between Israeli troops and Hezbollah guerrillas.

articles.headline: Auction Off for a Leader in Apparel
articles.snippet: The Jones Apparel Group, the $5 billion clothing conglomerate that owns Barneys New York, plans to abandon its months-long auction after failing to find a buyer willing to meet its price, people involved in the process said last night.      The mo...
articles.abstract: The Jones Apparel Group, the $5 billion clothing conglomerate that owns Barneys New York, plans to abandon its months-long auction after failing to find a buyer willing to meet its price, people involved in the process said last night.      The move, which could be announced as early as today, would be the first time that a major retail company had been forced to cancel a prominent auction at a time of intense interest in the sector by private equity firms, which have spent billions to buy retail companies like Neiman Marcus and Lord & Taylor.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Jones Apparel Group, the $5 billion clothing conglomerate that owns Barneys New York, plans to abandon its months-long auction after failing to find a buyer willing to meet its price, people involved in the process said last night.
articles.byline: By Andrew Ross Sorkin and Michael Barbaro

articles.headline: Marketers Trace Paths Users Leave on Internet
articles.snippet: If you use Yahoo's Web search engine to learn about hybrid cars, the site will quietly note that you fit into a group of users it calls ''Consciously Cruising.''      If you click on ads for moving van companies, you will join the ''Home Hopping''...
articles.abstract: If you use Yahoo's Web search engine to learn about hybrid cars, the site will quietly note that you fit into a group of users it calls ''Consciously Cruising.''      If you click on ads for moving van companies, you will join the ''Home Hopping'' group. Shop for wedding cakes and reception halls and you might be tagged as a future bride or groom.

articles.headline: A Generic Drug Tale, With an Ending Yet to Be Written
articles.snippet: The opening chapters of a draft autobiography sit amid the hundreds of pill bottles and mound of legal documents in Bernard C. Sherman's office. It will be the story of a brainy kid born in Toronto who becomes Canada's richest generic drug mogul. ...
articles.abstract: The opening chapters of a draft autobiography sit amid the hundreds of pill bottles and mound of legal documents in Bernard C. Sherman's office. It will be the story of a brainy kid born in Toronto who becomes Canada's richest generic drug mogul.     Though a work in progress, it has the makings of a page turner. One chapter will recount how an employee from a brand-name drug company offered to sell him secret files. Another, he says, will describe how Mr. Sherman caught a rival stealing the recipe for a blockbuster generic developed by his company, Apotex.
articles.lead_paragraph: The opening chapters of a draft autobiography sit amid the hundreds of pill bottles and mound of legal documents in Bernard C. Sherman's office. It will be the story of a brainy kid born in Toronto who becomes Canada's richest generic drug mogul.

articles.headline: A Woman to Be Chief at PepsiCo
articles.snippet: PepsiCo said yesterday that its president and chief financial officer, Indra K. Nooyi, would succeed Steven S. Reinemund as chief executive on Oct. 1, a move that makes the company one of the largest led by a woman.     ''I've been talking to the ...
articles.abstract: PepsiCo said yesterday that its president and chief financial officer, Indra K. Nooyi, would succeed Steven S. Reinemund as chief executive on Oct. 1, a move that makes the company one of the largest led by a woman.     ''I've been talking to the board about retirement for a year,'' Mr. Reinemund, 58, said yesterday in a conference call, ''but the seeds of this were really sown five years ago, when Indra was named president.'' Mr. Reinemund will stay as executive chairman until he retires in May.
articles.lead_paragraph: PepsiCo said yesterday that its president and chief financial officer, Indra K. Nooyi, would succeed Steven S. Reinemund as chief executive on Oct. 1, a move that makes the company one of the largest led by a woman.

articles.headline: Census Shows Growth of Immigrants
articles.snippet: The number of immigrants living in American households rose 16 percent over the last five years, fueled largely by recent arrivals from Mexico, according to fresh data released by the Census Bureau.     And increasingly, immigrants are bypassing t...
articles.abstract: The number of immigrants living in American households rose 16 percent over the last five years, fueled largely by recent arrivals from Mexico, according to fresh data released by the Census Bureau.     And increasingly, immigrants are bypassing the traditional gateway states like California and New York and settling directly in parts of the country that until recently saw little immigrant activity -- regions like the Upper Midwest, New England and the Rocky Mountain States.
articles.lead_paragraph: The number of immigrants living in American households rose 16 percent over the last five years, fueled largely by recent arrivals from Mexico, according to fresh data released by the Census Bureau.

articles.headline: Maybe the Toughest Job Aloft
articles.snippet: Jer'i Conway was the envy of her friends in 1969 when she became a flight attendant at United Airlines. She planned to stay about 18 months and then thought she would leave to be married, but the perks of free travel and other benefits kept her si...
articles.abstract: Jer'i Conway was the envy of her friends in 1969 when she became a flight attendant at United Airlines. She planned to stay about 18 months and then thought she would leave to be married, but the perks of free travel and other benefits kept her silver wings firmly on her uniform through the industry's best and leanest years.      For all her years of experience, though, she said she was not prepared for the news of the latest terror threat as she awoke last Thursday morning. ''It was just like I'd been sucker punched,'' said Ms. Conway, 56, who is based in San Francisco. ''It was 9/11 all over again. I started to cry.''
articles.lead_paragraph: Jer'i Conway was the envy of her friends in 1969 when she became a flight attendant at United Airlines. She planned to stay about 18 months and then thought she would leave to be married, but the perks of free travel and other benefits kept her silver wings firmly on her uniform through the industry's best and leanest years.

articles.headline: Dell Will Recall Batteries in PCs
articles.snippet: Dell is recalling 4.1 million notebook computer batteries because they could erupt in flames, the company said yesterday. It will be the largest safety recall in the history of the consumer electronics industry, the Consumer Product Safety Commiss...
articles.abstract: Dell is recalling 4.1 million notebook computer batteries because they could erupt in flames, the company said yesterday. It will be the largest safety recall in the history of the consumer electronics industry, the Consumer Product Safety Commission said.      Dell, the world's largest PC maker, said the lithium-ion batteries were made by Sony and were installed in notebooks sold from April 2004 to July 18 of this year.
articles.lead_paragraph: Dell is recalling 4.1 million notebook computer batteries because they could erupt in flames, the company said yesterday. It will be the largest safety recall in the history of the consumer electronics industry, the Consumer Product Safety Commission said.

articles.headline: Tighter Security Is Jeopardizing Orchestra Tours
articles.snippet: Air travel for classical musicians has never been easy.     Those husky cellos need an extra ticket. Hey, security! Watch that priceless Stradivarius. Double-reed players? They have long given up on carrying aboard those valuable knives and shapin...
articles.abstract: Air travel for classical musicians has never been easy.     Those husky cellos need an extra ticket. Hey, security! Watch that priceless Stradivarius. Double-reed players? They have long given up on carrying aboard those valuable knives and shaping tools used to mold the cane that transforms their breath into lyrical sounds.
articles.lead_paragraph: Air travel for classical musicians has never been easy.

articles.headline: Testing How Long the Mideast Cease-Fire Can Last
articles.snippet: Standing before flattened buildings in the shattered southern suburbs of Beirut, one of Hezbollah's two ministers in the Lebanese cabinet, Hassan Fadlallah, asserted Monday that Hezbollah had scored ''a divine victory'' in its conflict with Israel...
articles.abstract: Standing before flattened buildings in the shattered southern suburbs of Beirut, one of Hezbollah's two ministers in the Lebanese cabinet, Hassan Fadlallah, asserted Monday that Hezbollah had scored ''a divine victory'' in its conflict with Israel.     One of the key questions to be answered by that conflict was neatly reflected in the ruined setting Mr. Fadlallah chose.
